Tidying method for the acf function

Source: R/stats-time-series-tidiers.R
acf_tidiers.Rd

Tidy an "acf" object, which is the output of acf and the related pcf and ccf functions.

# S3 method for acf
tidy(x, ...)

Arguments

x

acf object
...

(not used)

Value

data.frame with columns

lag

lag values

acf

calculated correlation

Examples


# acf
result <- acf(lh, plot=FALSE)
tidy(result)
#> # A tibble: 17 x 2
#>      lag      acf
#>    <dbl>    <dbl>
#>  1     0  1.000  
#>  2     1  0.576  
#>  3     2  0.182  
#>  4     3 -0.145  
#>  5     4 -0.175  
#>  6     5 -0.150  
#>  7     6 -0.0210 
#>  8     7 -0.0203 
#>  9     8 -0.00420
#> 10     9 -0.136  
#> 11    10 -0.154  
#> 12    11 -0.0972 
#> 13    12  0.0490 
#> 14    13  0.120  
#> 15    14  0.0867 
#> 16    15  0.119  
#> 17    16  0.151  

# ccf
result <- ccf(mdeaths, fdeaths, plot=FALSE)
tidy(result)
#> # A tibble: 31 x 2
#>       lag     acf
#>     <dbl>   <dbl>
#>  1 -1.25   0.0151
#>  2 -1.17   0.366 
#>  3 -1.08   0.615 
#>  4 -1      0.708 
#>  5 -0.917  0.622 
#>  6 -0.833  0.340 
#>  7 -0.75  -0.0245
#>  8 -0.667 -0.382 
#>  9 -0.583 -0.612 
#> 10 -0.5   -0.678 
#> # ... with 21 more rows

# pcf
result <- pacf(lh, plot=FALSE)
tidy(result)
#> # A tibble: 16 x 2
#>      lag      acf
#>    <dbl>    <dbl>
#>  1     1  0.576  
#>  2     2 -0.223  
#>  3     3 -0.227  
#>  4     4  0.103  
#>  5     5 -0.0759 
#>  6     6  0.0676 
#>  7     7 -0.104  
#>  8     8  0.0120 
#>  9     9 -0.188  
#> 10    10  0.00255
#> 11    11  0.0656 
#> 12    12  0.0320 
#> 13    13  0.0219 
#> 14    14 -0.0931 
#> 15    15  0.230  
#> 16    16  0.0444 

# lag plot
library(ggplot2)
result <- tidy(acf(lh, plot=FALSE))
p <- ggplot(result, aes(x=lag, y=acf)) +
         geom_bar(stat='identity', width=0.1) +
         theme_bw()
p

# with confidence intervals
conf.level <- 0.95
# from `plot.acf` method
len.data <- length(lh) # same as acf$n.used
conf.int <- qnorm((1 + conf.level) / 2) / sqrt(len.data)
p + geom_hline(yintercept = c(-conf.int, conf.int),
               color='blue', linetype='dashed')

broom is a part of the tidyverse, an ecosystem of packages designed with common APIs and a shared philosophy. Learn more at tidyverse.org.

Developed by David Robinson.
